The conclusion is that Republican legislators champion denying the dignity of work to Americans but they champion providing Asians and South Americans the dignity of work.

The conclusion is the GOP does not support American capitalism. It steadfastly supports transferring to Asians and South Americans the process of turning raw materials, through the process of labor, into productive and profit-making commodities.

Sept 8, 1936, FDR stated, "In this country we insist, as an essential of the American way of life, that the employer-employee relationship should be one between free men and equals. We refuse to regard those who work with hand or brain as different from or inferior to those who live from their property. We insist that labor is entitled to as much respect as property. But our workers with hand and brain deserve more than respect for their labor. They deserve practical protection in the opportunity to use their labor at a return adequate to support them at a decent and constantly rising standard of living, and to accumulate a margin of security against the inevitable vicissitudes of life."

I come from a place where, if you run without getting the proper "approvals" from the proper "people", the "people" who object to your run will make their objections clear, starting by punching holes in your tires with a screwdriver and progressing from there.  No thanks.

No career is complete until you take a try a politics. Doesn't matter if its on the local school board, town planning commission, mayor, state representative, or like me the county budget committee. Give it a go. You and us, all Americans, will be better off if you do. For me I won the first three rounds of local elections and got TKO's in the fourth round when I ran for county commission.

What you get is an amazing sense of accomplishment and belonging to a committee. You also gain the right to make a stand for what you really believe in. Your core beliefs get challenged like they've never been challenged before. The first three elections I won were easy. People liked what I had to say so they voted for me. The fourth election, the one I lost was brutal. I lost by 6 votes. I knew I didn't have a chance in that one. I was the only progressive democrat on the ballot. Rotary, the Chamber of Commerce, and the Elks didn't invite me to speak at their political events. They invited all the republicans, but not the lone democrat. I was pro choice, pro environment, pro education, pro union, pro climate change and anti guns. Out of 5000 votes cast I came within 6 of winning in a solid red county.

Give it a try, we will all be better off if you do. Thanks David.

Whatever happened to enforcement of the antitrust laws that used to keep reasonable control over monopolies and price fixing? No doubt the corporate lobbyists have done a marvelous job of side tracking the attorney general and his staff away from attention to any annoying antitrust interference with our new class of corporate oligarchs. And Mr. Obama and his orations have never shown the slightest awareness of the need for action to put the merger and acquisition ogres back into
the antitrust legal box that used to be their proper container. Widespread competition used to be a fundamental function of our economic system but under the Bush/Obama administrations it has been allowed to become only a memory in which the suma wrestlers of corporate monopoly put on a meaningless competitive charade.

I don't think it is brave. I think it is cowardly. A cowardly abrogation of adult responsibility.

Dr. Deverall, I will concede that you have much more clinical experience than I with the imminent death of children suffering intractable pain.

No child should have that responsibility. The very definition of 'child' is that of one who cannot make adult decisions.

It is an adult responsibility, with the adult cognition to be aware of the guilt, horror, and grief that accompanies that decision. We cannot pass that responsibility to one who looks to all of us as protectors.

A child facing imminent death may say they are ready to go. We can take their word for it, value their wishes, and provide them with the best of final care.

I have no problem in baldly stating my opposition to capital punishment. As follows:

1) If the state has sanctions against murder, the state should not engage in murder.

2) State sanctioned murder has been shown, over and over again, to be discriminatory. By economic class, by race, by cognitive ability.

3) State sanctioned murder has been shown, over and over again, to make 'mistakes'. The innocent are murdered by the state. Victims were not responsible for the crime for which they were sentenced.
I think the problem is that the makers of those drugs no longer allow them to be sold or used for capital punishment.

I am pretty sure that if we can compassionately euthanize then we can enforce capital punishment in an effective, non-painful manner.  I wish the left would be intellectually honest about capital punishment.  Don't argue the pain issue, just say you have other reasons to oppose it.
Right on, St. David.
